name: Algoritmer og datastrukturer (ALG)
summary:
(This course is taught in English)

Teacher: Giovanni Bacci

Teaching Assistants: Alessandro Tibo, Christian Schilling, Khai Quang Ho, and Rasmus Hjelm Rasmussen

Study Secretary: Sidsel G. M. Overgaard

Description
An algorithm is a well-defined procedure to solve a specific problem. The study of algorithms is a key area of computer science that is essential for the development of correct and efficient software in any programming language. The course provides an introduction to the study of algorithms and data structures with a special focus on their design and analysis.

Textbook: Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein - Introduction to Algorithms, 3rd edition. The MIT Press, ISBN: 978-0-26253305-8

The course is 5 ECTS (~137,5 hrs) and is divided into 14 sessions: 12 regular sessions and 2 self-study sessions.

The exam will be in written form with external censors. Grades will be given according to the 7-points grading scale.

modules.name: Poll about Exercise Sessions Format (closes 23-02-2022 at 12:00)
modules.description: choose if you prefer help from TAs during the exercise sessions to be delivered only virtually (via MS Teams) or physically (in your group room).

name: Lecture 08: Binary Search Trees [6 April 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline
  • Binary Search Trees (BSTs)
  • Operations on BSTs
  • Red-Black Trees (RBTs)
  • Operations on RBTs

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for me to join you in your virtual room.

Readings

CLRS Ch. 12 until end of Section 12.3 and Ch. 13

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Meet with your group in your own group room. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for one of the TAs to come to your group room.

name: Lecture 07: Hash Tables [30 March 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline 
  • Direct-address tables
  • Hash tables
  • Hash functions
  • Open addressing

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for me to join you in your virtual room.

Readings: 

CLRS: Ch. 11 sections 11.1, 11.2, 11.3, and 11.4

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Meet with your group in your own group room. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for one of the TAs to come to your group room.

name: Self-study Session 1 [23 March 2022]
summary:
Part 1 (8:15 -- 10:00) 
  • the exercise sheet will be made available from 8:15
  • solve as many exercises as you can from the exercise sheet
  • write down your solutions as if this was a real-exam (i.e., strive for precision and clarity in your arguments)
  • work alone (you can look at the book or your notes, but you cannot get help from your peers or the TAs)
  • If some questions are not clear, I will be available in the ALG-F22 team for clarifications from 8:30 to 10:00
Part 2 (10:00 -- 12:00) 
  • discuss your solutions within your group in your group room
  • complete the exercises you did not solve on your own
  • the solution will be posted around 11:00. Use the last hour to discuss discrepancies between your solution and mine.
  • ask feedback to the TAs as a normal exercise session (use digital trashcan)
Pedagogical Remarks: 

  • the exercises are taken from old exams or they are slight adaptations. 
  • nevertheless, the exercise sheet does not represent an actual exam sheet
  • working individually during the first 2 hrs is meant to reproduce the conditions that you will find during the exam
  • exploit this opportunity to self-assess your preparation

name: Lecture 06: Elementary Data Structures [9 March 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline
  • Stacks and Queues
  • Linked Lists
  • Rooted Trees

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for me to join you in your virtual room.

Readings: 

CLRS Ch. 10 sections 10.1, 10.2, and 10.4

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Meet with your group in your own group room. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for one of the TAs to come to your group room.

name: Lecture 05: Sorting [2 March 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline
  • Heapsort  
  • Quicksort
  • Counting Sort
  • Radix Sort

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for me to join you in your virtual room. 

Readings:

CLRS Ch6 until 6.4 (included), Ch7 until Best-case Partitioning, Ch8 section 8.2 and 8.3

Optional Readings: 

CLRS Ch7 pp. 175-178 and pp.191-193

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Meet with your group in your own group room. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for one of the TAs come to your group room.

name: Lecture 04: Recurrences & The Master Method [24 February 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline:

We present three useful techniques to perform asymptotic running time analysis of recursive algorithms

  • the substitution method
  • the recursion-tree method
  • the master method

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for me to join you in your virtual room. 

Readings

CLRS Ch4 excluding Sec. 4.1, 4.2, and 4.6

Optional readings

CLRS Ch4 - Sec. 4.6

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Meet with your group in your own group room. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait for one of the TAs come to your group room.

name: Lecture 03: Divide-and-Conquer: Merge Sort [17 February 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline:
  • Algorithm Design: Divide and Conquer 
  • Merge sort (Correctness & Runtime Analysis)

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help.

Readings:

CLRS Ch2 only section 2.3

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Meet with your group in your own group room and solve the exercise sheet. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help. This time the TAs and I will be physically present.

name: Lecture 02: Insertion sort & Asymptotic notation [9 February 2022]
summary:
Lecture Outline:
  • Insertion sort
  • Loop invariants for proving correctness
  • Asymptotic notation & Asymptotic analysis

I will be available for questions from 8:30 to 10:00 in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help.

Readings:

CLRS: Ch 2 (pp 16-29) and Ch3 (pp. 43-53, read by yourself small-«math xmlns=¨http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML¨»«mi»§#959;«/mi»«/math» and small-«math xmlns=¨http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML¨»«mi»§#969;«/mi»«/math» notation)

Optional Readings:

Refresh your knowledge on some basic properties of common functions such as logarithm, polynomials, exponential, factorial, etc. CLRS: Ch 3 (pp. 53-60

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)
Work together with your group in your group room (if you wish you may still use your virtual group room). Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and wait in your virtual group room in the ALG-F22 team for one of the TAs to join you.

name: Lecture 01: Algorithms, Correctness, and Efficiency [2 February 2022]
summary:
We will meet virtually at 8:15 in the ALG-F22 team where I will present the course and its structure.

Lecture Outline:
  • Algorithms & pseudocode
  • The correctness of an algorithm
  • Efficiency & order of growth
  • Case Study: find an element in a sequence of numbers

I will be available for questions in the ALG-F22 team. Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help and I will join you in your virtual room.

Readings: CLRS: Ch 1 (pp 1-15), Ch 2 (pp 20-24)

Exercise Session (10:00 - 12:00)

Likely, group formation has not been completed yet. For this time you may just form groups by randomly choosing a virtual group room in the ALG-F22 team:

  • DAT students can choose a room in the interval A316-A324
  • SW students can choose a room in the intervals A217-A226, A302-A313, A325
  • DV students can choose a room in the interval B217-B219

Use the Digital trashcan to ask for help. One of the TAs will join you in your virtual group room.
